newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy govt says will not bring forward 1998 budget.
newsitem.headline: Italy govt says will not bring forward 1998 budget.

text.p: Italian cabinet undersecretary Enrico Micheli said on Thursday that the 1998 budget would not be brought forward.
Asked by reporters if an early budget was possible, Micheli said: "I don't think so. The time frame is the usual one."
Micheli's remarks appeared to scotch proposals earlier this year that the budget should be brought forward to show Italy's commitment to meeting the European economic and monetary goals.
The Italian government has to present its budget in September and the bill must by law be approved by both houses of parliament before the end of the year.

Prime Minister Romano Prodi has introduced just under 100 trillion lire of belt-tightening measures over the past year as he fights to lower the budget deficit to three percent of Gross Domestic Product as demanded for single currency aspirants.
Micheli added that the DPEF, the government's three-year economic planning document, would be presented in May.
